item.description:
PHOENIX ART AFTER HOURS

5:30 - 8:00 pm
$5 / Free for Phoenix Employees, Museum Members

BAILA Y CANTA
Enjoy the music and movement of Mexico with the
Mariachi Trovadores de America and traditional Mexican
dancers
CHICA BONITA
Try Ada Rios’ health and beauty products based on ancient
Mayan recipes from Mexico and Guatemala
VAYA CON DIOS                                                                  
Be a Mayan deity in Balam Soto’s interactive art activity
TEQUILA
Sample tequilas and Mexican food from Puerto Vallarta
Restaurant while supplies last.


 

 

FILM AT 8 PM Backyard
  Mexican police officer Blanca Bravo is sent to Cuidad Juarez to investigate    and comes to learn realities of these women's lives, An astonishing fictional account of the unending series of murders of young women in Ciudad Juarez, Mexico, which began in 1996. 2009. Mexico. 122 min. Not Rated. Subtitles. Directed by Carlos Carrera

 Current exhibit:

Monet's Water Lilies: An Artist's Obsession

February 17 - June 12, 2011

The painter Claude Monet moved to Giverny in 1883 and ten years later acquired an adjoining plot of land across from his house. Inspired by his love for Japanese prints, he began to transform the space into a water garden and built a Japanese style bridge at the north end from which he could observe the flowers.

Monet devoted a great deal of time, energy, and money to his garden projects and ultimately employed six gardeners at Giverny. He began to paint scenes of the water garden and Japanese bridge in the late 1890s and these eventually became obsessive themes for the rest of his life. From age 74-86 (from 1899-1926) Monet produced more than 300 paintings of these watery floral subjects. They can be seen as the final flowering of Impressionist concerns with atmosphere and nature.

The exhibition features paintings lent by public and private collections from around America and provide a meaningful overview of Monet’s development during these final productive years and reveal the range of approaches he adopted.

In addition to the paintings, the exhibition and accompanying publication will feature a selection of period photographs of Monet and his water lily garden as well as photographs of the gardens as they look today.
 

In addition to parking on the street, (after 6 free), convenient parking available at the Front Street Garage, off Prospect Street, behind the museum.
item.why: a chance to mix and mingle.
item.name: PHOENIX ART AFTER HOURS
